questions.text: A couple with a 5-year-old son diagnosed with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is expecting another child. The mother, currently pregnant, is concerned about her unborn daughter potentially having the same condition, despite both parents being clinically unaffected. Considering the genetic nature of G6PD deficiency, which of the following statements is true regarding the risk to the female fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The baby has a 50% chance of being a carrier

 

Explanation:

 

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder.

 

  • Males (XY) with the defective gene on the X chromosome are affected, as they have only one X.
    • Females (XX) need two defective X chromosomes to be affected, but if they have only one defective X, they are typically carriers (and usually asymptomatic, though some may show mild symptoms due to lyonization/inactivation of the normal X).

 

In this scenario:

 

  • The son is affected, so he must have inherited the defective X from his mother.
  • Since father is unaffected, his X chromosome is normal.
  • The mother must be a carrier (Xá´ºXáµˆ) â€“ one normal (Xá´º), one defective (Xáµˆ).

 

Now, for a female fetus, she will inherit:

 

  • One X from father â†’ always normal (Xá´º)
  • One X from mother â†’ 50% chance of getting normal (Xá´º), 50% chance of defective (Xáµˆ)

 

Thus, the daughter will be:

 

  • 50% Xá´ºXá´º â†’ not a carrier
  • 50% Xá´ºXáµˆ â†’ carrier

 

Hence, 50% chance of being a carrier.

 

Final Answer: B. The baby has a 50% chance of being a carrier

 

 

Educational Objectives:

 

G6PD deficiency is the most common enzyme deficiency leading to hemolytic anemia. It affects the pentose phosphate pathway, reducing the production of NADPH, which is essential for maintaining reduced glutathione that protects cells from oxidative damage. This condition predominantly affects males, while female carriers are usually asymptomatic.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 693-694.

questions.text: A 3-day-old infant exhibits difficulty feeding, cyanosis post-feeding, general hypotonia, and a detectable heart murmur. On examination, the infant has a flat occiput, epicanthic folds, and a single palmar crease. There is a noted family history of Down syndrome. Given these clinical findings, which karyotype result from the chromosome analysis provided would you expect to find in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Result C

 

Option C:

 

Clinical clues:

  • 3-day-old with:
    • Feeding difficulty, cyanosis, hypotonia.
    • Heart murmur.
    • Flat occiput, epicanthic folds, single palmar crease.
  • Family history of Down syndrome.

 

All signs are classic for Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) 

 

As seen in the karyotype of image C 

47 chromosomes total, Three copies of chromosome 21

 

 Explanation:

 

Option A. Result: Would likely represent a normal karyotype, which would not be consistent with the clinical presentation of Down syndrome.

 

Option B. Result: Could indicate another chromosomal abnormality that does not align with Down syndrome's typical presentation, possibly a translocation or deletion.

 

Option D. Result: Could indicate another chromosomal abnormality that does not align with Down syndrome's typical presentation, possibly a translocation or deletion 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Down syndrome is characterized by an extra copy of chromosome 21, which is a trisomy.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 635

choices.text: Initiation of dystrophin transcription will be defective.
Termination of dystrophin transcription will be defective.
Capping and splicing of dystrophin messenger RNA will be defective.
Tailing of dystrophin messenger RNA will be defective.

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic in New Delhi, a 5-year-old child is diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy, a severe muscle-wasting disease. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the promoter region of the gene responsible for producing dystrophin, a crucial muscle protein. Considering the role of promoter regions in gene expression, which of the following is the most likely consequence of this mutation on dystrophin production?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Initiation of dystrophin transcription will be defective 

 

Option A:  

                                                                          

  • Mutations in the promoter region prevents the formation of RNA polymerase II transcription complex ðŸ¡ªdecrease in the initiation of mRNA synthesis.

  • A deficiency of dystrophin mRNA will lead to deficiency of the dystrophin protein.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Termination defects are related to sequences and factors at the end of the gene, not the promoter region.

 

Option C: Capping and splicing are post-transcriptional modifications and generally not directly affected by promoter mutations.

 

Option D: Polyadenylation (tailing) is another post-transcriptional event typically not influenced by mutations in the promoter region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A mutation in the promoter region of the dystrophin gene with Duchenne muscular dystrophy, is likely to impair the initiation of dystrophin transcription. This is because the promoter region is essential for the start of transcription, and its mutation disrupts the normal production of dystrophin, a key protein for muscle function.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 655

choices.text: Single nucleotides change in a codon

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with severe abdominal pain, recurrent infections, and a history of chronic hemolytic anemia. On examination, he has a non-healing ulcer on his right leg, and a peripheral blood smear shows abnormally shaped red blood cells. What is the basic genetic defect associated with this disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Single nucleotide change in a codon.

 

Option A:

 

  • This is a case of sickle cell anemia causing production of abnormal Hemoglobin HbS.

  • HbS arises from a point mutation which substitutes thymine for adenine in the 6th codon of the beta-globin chain gene, GTG at the place of GAG ðŸ¡ª causes coding of valine [GTG] instead of glutamate [GAG] in position 6 of the Hb beta chain.

  • Resulting Hb: forms polymers under deoxy conditions, exhibits changes in solubility and molecular stability ðŸ¡ª these properties are responsible for the profound clinical expressions of the sickling syndromes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Autoantibodies against RBC membrane: are seen in AIHA (autoimmune haemolytic anemia).

 

Option C. Genomic imprinting: in this, expression of some genes depends on whether or not they are inherited maternally or paternally e.g. Angelman syndrome.

 

Option D. Triple nucleotide repeats: These are associated with diseases such as CGG repeat sequence - fragile X syndrome, CAG repeats - Huntingtonâ€™s chorea, CTG -myotonic dystrophy and CAG in spinobulbar muscular atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused by a single nucleotide substitution in the Î²-globin gene, which leads to the replacement of glutamic acid with valine at the sixth position of the Î²-globin chain. This single amino acid change results in the production of hemoglobin S (HbS), which polymerizes under low-oxygen conditions, causing the red blood cells to take on a sickle shape and leading to hemolytic anemia.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 58, 417.

questions.text: During a routine evaluation, a 4-year-old boy with developmental delays is noted to have distinct facial features, including a long face and large ears, along with macroorchidism. The boy's family history reveals a pattern of intellectual disability predominantly affecting male relatives. Based on the clinical presentation and family history, the physician suspects a genetic condition characterized by a trinucleotide repeat expansion. Which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fragile X syndrome

 

Option C:

 

Fragile X syndrome has an abnormal genetic makeup - increase in number of trinucleotide repeat sequences (microsatellite instability).

 

  • C/F includes enlarged testes (most specific), mental retardation.
  • Larger the number of repeats, higher is the probability of retardation.
  • Affected sisters have mild MR than their brothers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder involving a missing or partially missing X chromosome, affecting only females, and is characterized by short stature and ovarian dysfunction, not intellectual disability.

 

Option B: Edwards syndrome, or trisomy 18, is a chromosomal condition associated with a wide spectrum of severe clinical manifestations, including profound developmental delays and structural anomalies; it is not a trinucleotide repeat disorder.

 

Option D: Klinefelter syndrome is characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome in males (47, XXY) and is associated with hypogonadism and reduced fertility, but not typically with the facial features or intellectual disability pattern seen in Fragile X syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p378, DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 578.

choices.text: 47, XX, +21/46, XX

questions.text: A female patient presents with features suggestive of Down syndrome. However, not all cells appear to have the typical trisomy 21 on karyotype analysis. Some of her cells have a normal karyotype. Which of the following is the correct cytogenetic notation for this presentation of Down syndrome mosaicism?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 47, XX, +21/46, XX

 

Option D:

 

The correct notation for a female with Down syndrome mosaicism is "47, XX, +21/46,XX," which indicates that there are two cell lines; one with trisomy 21 (47 chromosomes including an extra chromosome 21) and one with the normal chromosomal count (46 chromosomes).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: 47, XX, +21: This notation indicates a non-mosaic form of Down syndrome where all cells have an extra chromosome 21.

 

Option B: 46, XX: This represents a normal female karyotype with no extra chromosomes.

 

Option C: 47, XX, +18: This would indicate trisomy 18, not Down syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mosaicism occurs when a chromosomal anomaly affects one of several precursor cells of an embryo or tissue.
  • The two or more karyotypes which characterize the mosaic cells are separated by a slash in cytogenetic notation.
  • The nomenclature 47, XX, +21 denotes a cell line typical of a female with trisomy 21 (Down syndrome)
  • 46, XX is the karyotype expected for a normal female and XY sex chromosomes refer to a male
  • About 95% of patients with Down syndrome have trisomy 21, while 3% to 4% have translocations and 1% mosaicism.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 324, 635.

choices.text: She has a 25% chance of having Tay-Sachs disease.
She has a 50% chance of having Tay-Sachs disease.
She is a carrier for Tay-Sachs disease.

questions.text: A genetic counsellor is reviewing the case of an Ashkenazi Jewish family with a 7-month-old son diagnosed with Tay-Sachs disease, an autosomal recessive disorder. If son is a diagnosed case of Tay-Sachs disease. The family's pedigree and Southern blot analysis, with RFLP linked to the Tay-Sachs gene, have been presented to determine the genetic status of their daughter. What does the Southern blot analysis indicate regarding the daughter's genetic status concerning Tay-Sachs disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. She is homozygous normal.                    

 

Option D:

From the pedigree and Southern blot:

  • The son has Tay-Sachs disease (as mentioned in question), which is autosomal recessive, meaning he has two mutant alleles.
  • The father and mother must both be carriers (heterozygous), since their son has the disease.
  • The Southern blot shows RFLP patterns linked to the Tay-Sachs gene for all family members.

 

Looking at the band patterns:

  • The son (affected) shows only the 3 kb bands, which must represent the disease allele.
  • The father shows both 3 kb and 4 kb bands, indicating he's a carrier.
  • The mother shows both 3 kb and 4 kb bands, indicating she's a carrier.

 

The daughter shows only 4 kb bands. so she must be homozygous normal for the  gene.

 

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. 25% chance of having Tay-Sachs disease: This is a statistical likelihood for offspring when both parents are carriers, but it speaks more to probability than to actual genetic findings from the analysis of Southern blot.

 

Option B. 50% chance of having Tay-Sachs disease: This might be considered if one parent is affected and the other is a carrier, but it speaks more to probability than to actual genetic findings from the analysis of Southern blot.

 

Option C. Carrier for Tay-Sachs disease: This would mean the child inherited one normal and one mutated gene. The absence of the mutated gene in  Southern blot analysis  negates this option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Southern blot analysis is a method used to detect specific DNA sequences, making it valuable for diagnosing genetic conditions. In the context of Tay-Sachs disease, which is an autosomal recessive disorder, a person must inherit two defective copies of the gene to manifest the disease.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 635

From the below chromosome analysis, which of the results is most likely in this case?

Option B. Result: Could indicate another chromosomal abnormality that does not align with Down syndrome's typical presentation, possibly a translocation or deletion.

questions.text: In a family affected by Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, restriction analysis of the genomic region surrounding the CMT gene on chromosome 17 produces one large abnormal fragment and one smaller fragment common to unaffected controls. Based on this information, what is the most likely pattern of inheritance for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease in this family?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Autosomal dominant

 

Option B:

 

  • DNA duplication is one form of atypical inheritance.
  • The large fragment could derive from a mutation ablating one flanking restriction site or from extra DNA inserted between the restriction sites.
  • There are two DNA fragment sizes in the affected individual but one in controls suggests alteration of only one of the two homologous CMT regions on chromosome 17. The production of disease by alteration of one homologous locus (one abnormal allele) causes autosomal dominant inheritance.
  • This form of CMT is caused by a duplication of the PMP22 gene, a gene encoding a peripheral myelin protein and an extra copy of PMP22 increases protein abundance and interferes with nerve conduction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. X-linked recessive: This is less likely since Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, especially types associated with chromosome 17 mutations, typically does not follow an X-linked pattern of inheritance.

 

Option C. Autosomal recessive: In autosomal recessive conditions, two mutated alleles are necessary for the manifestation of the disease, which does not align with the finding of one normal and one abnormal fragment.

 

Option D. X-linked dominant: This is also unlikely for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, given its known genetic basis and typical autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, particularly for mutations found on chromosome 17, which often involve the PMP22 gene. The presence of one abnormal fragment in the restriction analysis suggests a mutation or alteration in one allele of the gene, while the other allele appears normal (as indicated by the smaller fragment seen in controls). This pattern is consistent with autosomal dominant inheritance, where a single mutated allele can cause the disease phenotype.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 635

choices.text: Germ-line gene therapy to replace one ADA gene copy
Germ-line gene therapy to replace both ADA gene copies
Somatic cell gene therapy to replace both ADA gene copy in circulating lymphocytes
Somatic cell gene therapy to replace one ADA gene copy in bone marrow lymphoblasts

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy with chronic yeast diaper rash and multiple episodes of pneumonia, including blood cultures positive for Group A streptococcus, is suspected to have a compromised immune system. Given the rarity of Group A strep infections in infants and the indications of defective B-cells and T-cells, his physician diagnoses him with severe combined immune deficiency (SCID). Which treatment could permanently cure the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Somatic cell gene therapy to replace one ADA gene copy in bone marrow lymphoblasts.

 

Option D:

 

  • Gene therapy refers to a group of techniques by which gene structure or expression is altered to ameliorate a disease.
  • Germ-line therapy involving alterations of genes in primordial germ cells is not being explored in humans. But performed in animals that alters the characteristics of offspring rather than the treated individuals.
  • Somatic cell gene therapy is targeted to an affected tissue or group of tissues in the individual and is most effective if stem cells such as bone marrow can be treated. It helps in replacing damaged tissue without the rejection problems of transplantation. For autosomal recessive disorders, only one of the two defective alleles must be replaced or supplemented.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Somatic gene therapy to correct stem cells such as bone marrow would give a continuous source of ADA enzyme and curative therapy; germ-line therapy would target his spermatogonia and thus future offspring.

 

Option B & Option C: For autosomal recessive disorders, only one of the two defective alleles should be replaced or supplemented to allow normal enzyme function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The permanent cure for SCID, especially for ADA-SCID (adenosine deaminase deficiency), typically involves gene therapy that targets the bone marrow cells, as these are the progenitors of the immune system. Somatic cell gene therapy targeting the bone marrow can lead to the development of a functional immune system.

 

Ref: Harper 31 e: p 1086.

questions.text: During a medical conference on the advancements in genetic treatments, a speaker highlights the milestone of the first successful gene therapy targeting a somatic enzyme deficiency. This groundbreaking therapy was primarily applied to treat which condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SCID

 

Option A:

 

The first successful gene therapy was applied to treat Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID), specifically a form known as ADA-SCID (adenosine deaminase deficiency SCID). This therapy involved inserting a functional copy of the ADA gene into the patient's own blood cells, correcting the enzyme deficiency and restoring immune function.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Cancer: While gene therapy is being explored for cancer treatment, it was not the first condition successfully treated with gene therapy.

 

Option C: Haemophilia: Gene therapy has shown promise in treating haemophilia, but it was not the first disease targeted by successful gene therapy.

 

Option D: Cystic fibrosis: Gene therapy trials have been conducted for cystic fibrosis, but the first successful application of gene therapy was for SCID.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dr French Anderson did the first gene therapy to treat SCID.
  • Gene Therapy is the intracellular delivery of genes to produce a therapeutic effect by correcting an existing abnormality.
  • It is divided into:
  1. Somatic cell gene therapy - Gene is introduced into somatic cells.
  2. Germ cell gene therapy (Transgenic animal).

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 648.

questions.text: A newly married couple visits a genetic counseling clinic as they are expecting their first child. Their medical history reveals that both the husband and wife carry the sickle-cell trait. The couple is aware of the genetic implications and is seeking advice on the likelihood of their child being affected by sickle-cell anemia. Given that both parents are carriers of the sickle-cell trait, what is the risk that their offspring will inherit sickle-cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 25%    

 

Option D:

                                                             

  • Sickle cell anemia is a disease with autosomal recessive inheritance, due to mutation in the beta-globin gene.
  • When both parents are having sickle-cell trait (carriers of the abnormal gene) the risk of offspring getting affected would be 25% (sickle-cell anemia with two abnormal genes).
  • The chances of having a child as a carrier would be 50% (sickle –cell trait with one abnormal gene) and a normal child is 25% (no abnormal gene).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: 100% and Option B: 75%: If the disease is with Mendelian inheritance, the risk to the offspring would be more than 50%. E.g: if both parents have (homozygous state) sickle cell anemia, then the risk would be 100%.

 

Option C: 50%: For diseases with autosomal dominant inheritance like Huntington's chorea the risk of child getting affected is 50% if one parent is affected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inheritance Pattern –

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 608-611.

questions.text: During a pediatric residency rotation, residents are presented with a case of a 1-year-old girl who exhibits severe psychomotor retardation, skeletal anomalies, and coarse facial features. Extensive lysosomal enzyme testing reveals low activities of mannosidase, fructosidase, glucuronidase, and galactosidase in leukocytes and fibroblasts, while high levels of these enzymes are observed in plasma. Based on these clinical and laboratory findings, the residents are asked to determine the most likely diagnosis. What condition does this child most likely have?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inclusion cell disease

 

Option A:

 

  • Inclusion cell (I-cell) disease is a condition in which lysosomes lack in enzymes but are seen in blood.
  • Mannose-6-phosphate is the marker enzyme to target the nascent enzymes to lysosomes.
  • In I CELL DISEASE - the carbohydrate units are not added to the enzyme →Mannose-6-phosphate deficient enzymes cannot reach their destination (protein targeting defect).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B.  Zellweger syndrome is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomes are empty or peroxisomal enzymes are not transported correctly into peroxisomes → leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA → accumulation of VLCFA in CNS → neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

Option C. It is also a peroxisomal disorder→ phytanic acid accumulation along with VLCFA & Children do not survive long.

 

Option D. Due to lack of alpha-hydroxylase → alpha oxidation does not occur → phytanic acid accumulates in the tissues → C/F: severe neurological symptoms, polyneuropathy, retinitis pigmentosa, nerve deafness and cerebellar ataxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inclusion cell (I-cell) disease, or mucolipidosis type II, is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by defective trafficking of lysosomal enzymes. Normally, these enzymes are targeted to the lysosomes within cells; however, in I-cell disease, they are mistakenly secreted outside the cell, leading to low enzyme activity in cells (like leukocytes and fibroblasts) and high levels in the plasma. The clinical features described, including psychomotor retardation, skeletal anomalies, and coarse facial features, align with the presentation of I-cell disease.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p586.

questions.text: Which of the following factor is recognized as capable of converting a normal cell into a cancer cell?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ionizing radiation: It can cause direct DNA damage, leading to mutations that may result in cancer if not properly repaired.

 

Option B. Mutagenic chemicals: These substances can interact with DNA to cause mutations, some of which might confer a growth advantage to cells, leading to cancer.

 

Option C. Oncogenic viruses: Certain viruses have the ability to integrate their genetic material into the host cell's genome, potentially activating oncogenes or inactivating tumor suppressor genes, thereby inducing tumorigenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Substances which increase the rate of mutation in turn enhance the rate of incidence of cancer → hence, all carcinogens are mutagens.
  • E.g: Radiations: X-rays, gamma rays, ultraviolet rays.
  • Chemicals: (a) occupation (aniline, asbestos), (b) diet (aflatoxins), (c) lifestyle (smoking).
  • Oncogenic viruses: Epstein-Barr virus, Human papillomavirus, Hepatitis B virus, Hepatitis C virus, Human immunodeficiency virus etc

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 711.

questions.text: In a cardiology clinic, a 25-year-old male presents with intermittent chest pain lasting about 10 minutes, a recent onset of visual difficulties, and notable physical characteristics. On examination, the patient is observed to be tall and thin with long extremities. A slit lamp examination reveals an upward dislocation of the lens in the right eye, and an echocardiogram indicates aortic regurgitation. Based on these findings, the cardiologist is considering a specific diagnosis. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Marfan syndrome

 

Option A:

 

  • Marfan syndrome is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait.
  • Due to a defect in the gene, coding for a connective tissue protein, fibrillin-1.
  • Arachnodactyly (long digits), ectopia lentis (dislocation of lens), hyperextension of joints, aortic aneurysm are classical manifestations of the syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Menke’s Disease is due to deficiency of copper  → defective function of lysyl oxidase → reduced cross linkage of collagen.

 

Option C. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is due to defective Type III collagen formation due to defect in lysyl oxidase or lysyl hydroxylase → resulting in weakening of collagen, loose skin, hypermobile and lax joints.

 

Option D. Alport Syndrome is due to defective Type IV collagen → abnormalities in glomerular basement membrane →  hematuria; progress to kidney failure

 

Educational objective:

 

Marfan syndrome, a genetic connective tissue disorder; Key features are tall stature with long extremities, lens dislocation (ectopia lentis), and cardiovascular abnormalities such as aortic regurgitation. Marfan syndrome is known to affect the skeletal system, eyes, and cardiovascular system.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 723.

questions.text: An oncology resident is reviewing the genetic underpinnings of various cancers and comes across a case of retinoblastoma, a rare pediatric eye cancer. The resident recalls that a specific genetic mutation is known to play a key role in the development of this cancer. Which gene, when mutated, is most commonly associated with the development of retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RB1 gene

 

Option D:

 

  • RB protein (isolated from retinoblastoma patients) is the product of an oncosuppressor gene.
  • It is a cell cycle regulator, which binds and inactivates the E2F, a transcription factor → inhibition of cell cycle at G1 phase.
  • In controlled cell cycles, cyclin D levels rise in the late G1 phase.
  • The cyclin D inactivates Rb, which is separated from E2F: normal mechanism to overcome the G1 arrest by Rb → Thus, Rb cannot inhibit cell cycle → continuous cell division and cancer.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A, B. Genes causing cancer are oncogenes. e.g., myc, src, ras, abl, erb-B etc

 

Option D. Genes which protect the individual from cancer are Anti-oncogenes or Oncosuppressor e.g., p53, pRB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma is most commonly associated with a mutation in the RB1 gene, which codes for the retinoblastoma protein (pRb). This protein is a tumor suppressor that regulates the cell cycle. Mutations in RB1 can lead to a loss of this regulatory function, allowing cells to proliferate uncontrollably and resulting in cancer.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 744.

questions.text: A 5-month-old girl of Ashkenazi Jewish descent, after a period of normal development, shows a plateau in developmental milestones. Initially exhibiting normal behaviors such as rolling over and smiling, she becomes less active and is unable to sit. Upon examination, her pediatrician in India notes hypotonia and an exaggerated startle reflex. An ophthalmologic examination reveals a cherry-red spot, leading to the suspicion of a lipid storage disease. Considering the family's background and the symptoms, what is the risk that the next child will also be affected by this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1/4

 

Option C:

 

  • The symptoms are suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease, an autosomal recessive disorder involving neurodegeneration and early death.
  • Metabolic diseases exhibit autosomal or X-linked recessive inheritance and in this female patient it is likely an autosomal disease.
  • The child’s parents are obligate carriers and have one-fourth chance (25% recurrence risk) that their next child will be affected.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Developmental plateau, hypotonia, exaggerated startle reflex, and a cherry-red spot on ophthalmologic examination, is classic for Tay-Sachs disease, a type of lipid storage disease more commonly found among individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Tay-Sachs disease is an autosomal recessive disorder, which means that for a child to be affected, they must inherit two copies of the defective gene, one from each parent.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 635, Lewis, pp 82-86. Scriver, pp 3827-3876.

choices.text: Abnormal structure of cilia

questions.text: A couple has been seeking infertility treatment after 10 years of marriage. The wife's examination shows no significant findings. However, the husband has a history of bronchiectasis, situs inversus since childhood, and recurrent sinusitis. Further investigation reveals that he is sterile. What is the most likely cause of his infertility?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Abnormal structure of cilia

 

Option A:

 

  • Kartagener syndrome, an AR disorder characterized by bronchiectasis, sinusitis, and situs inversus.
  • It is associated with the absence of inner or outer dynein arms in the cilia ðŸ¡ª leads to abnormal ciliary mobility of the sperm ðŸ¡ª infertility.
  • Ciliary abnormalities in the respiratory tract ðŸ¡ª sinusitis and bronchiectasis. So it is classified as an “immotile cilia syndrome”. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Abnormal levels of sphingomyelinase: Sphingomyelinase deficiency results in Niemann-Pick disease ðŸ¡ª accumulation of Sphingomyelin in the phagocytes (Foam histocytes) → deposit in the liver, spleen, lymph nodes, and skin.

C/F: hepatosplenomegaly, neurologic deterioration and no survival beyond 3 years of age.

 

Option C. Fibrillin deficiency: Results in Marfan syndrome. C/F: Patients look tall and thin, arachnodactyly, ectopia lentis and aortic dilation leading to aortic aneurysm.

 

Option D. 47, XXY karyotype: Seen in Klinefelter syndrome, characterized by male hypogonadism causing male infertility (as given in the case), atrophic testes, tall stature, gynecomastia, and mental retardation (Other features are not suggestive of the diagnosis).

 

Educational objective:

 

Kartagener's syndrome, which is a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia. This condition is characterized by a triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis. It is caused by defects in the structure and function of ciliary motility, which affects not only respiratory cilia but also the cilia within the reproductive tract, leading to infertility due to impaired sperm motility.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 665.

questions.text: Sickle cell anemia is characterized by a mutation in the β-globin gene, resulting in the substitution of glutamic acid with valine at the sixth position of the β-globin chain. What mechanism most likely underlies this specific genetic alteration?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Single-base substitution (point mutation)

 

Option D:

 

  • A change from one DNA codon to another cause’s replacement of amino acids such as valine to glutamic acid, changes in the β-globin peptide chain of haemoglobin S.
  • A single nucleotide substitution (point mutation) would affect such a codon change and involves a thymine to adenine substitution at the second position of the codon 6.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Equal exchange (crossing over) among homologous β-globin genes could exchange alleles, by replacing normal alleles with mutant partners, or vice versa (converting heterozygosity to homozygosity). Unequal crossing over could generate mutant alleles with duplicated or deficient nucleotides but not substitution.

 

Option (B, C): One or two-base insertions changes the reading frame of the genetic code (frame-shift mutation) and usually produces a termination codon (chain-termination mutation) after the point of insertion. A three-base deletion will cause a deletion of an amino acid from protein and not substitution.

 

Educational objective:

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused by a single-base substitution in the β-globin gene, where adenine is replaced by thymine. This point mutation leads to the change from glutamic acid to valine at the sixth amino acid position in the β-globin chain, which significantly alters the hemoglobin's properties and leads to the characteristic sickling of red blood cells under low oxygen conditions.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 635

questions.text: A 25-year-old white woman and a 28-year-old white man are seeking genetic counselling in an Indian metropolitan hospital. They have a family history of cystic fibrosis affecting one of their siblings. Considering their concern about the risk of transmitting this autosomal recessive disorder to their future offspring, which genetic testing method would be most appropriate to assess their carrier status?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polymerase chain reaction (PCR)                      

 

Option C:

 

  • Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disease due to point mutations or deletions in the gene encoding a chloride transporter (an integral membrane protein). 
  • An amplification of the mutated region using the PCR can be done → products are sequenced → compared with the normal sequence for this region.
  • If comparison shows deletion → the donor DNA would be the carrier. 
  • If no mutation → DNA donor as a carrier of cystic fibrosis is reduced, but still exists

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Biochemical testing: used to detect a defective enzyme or a decrease in levels of a normal enzyme. E.g. detects carriers of AR diseases such as Tay-Sachs disease, sickle cell anemia, and thalassemia.

 

Option B: Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH): used to detect micro deletions in a gene but can’t detect a single base change.

 

Option D: Karyotype analysis: used to detect monosomies, trisomy, translocations, inversions, and deletions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is the most appropriate method for detecting specific mutations in the CFTR gene associated with cystic fibrosis. PCR can amplify the regions of interest to determine if the couple carries the common mutations causing the disease.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: P 483.

choices.text: Northern blotting of red blood cell mRNA
Enzyme assay of red blood cell hemolysate
Western blotting of red blood cell hemolysates
Amplification of red blood cell DNA and hybridization with allele-specific oligonucleotides (PCR-ASOs)

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy, who had been receiving a sulphonamide antibiotic as a preventive measure for recurrent urinary tract infections, presents with worsening illness, pallor, and irritability. Laboratory findings reveal severe anemia and jaundice, indicative of hemolysis. Which test is the simplest for diagnosing his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enzyme assay of red blood cell hemolysate

 

Option B:

 

  • Tropical African and Mediterranean peoples have highest prevalence because sickle cell trait confers resistance to malaria.
  • The phenotype of jaundice and RBC hemolysis with anemia is triggered by a variety of infections, drugs and dietary substances in fava beans.
  • Sulphonamide and antimalarial drugs are noted for inducing hemolysis in G6PD- deficient individuals, which exhibits X- linked recessive inheritance, explains why male offspring but not the parents become ill when exposed to antimalarials.
  • Red cell hemolysis after drug exposure suggests a red cell enzyme defect, confirmed by enzyme assay to demonstrate deficient activity. A most likely diagnosis is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, the most common genetic disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Northern blotting of red blood cell mRNA is a complex procedure that is not typically used in a clinical setting for this purpose.

 

Option C: Western blotting of red blood cell hemolysates could theoretically detect the presence of G6PD protein, but it is not a quantitative assay and is more complex than an enzyme activity assay.

 

Option D: Amplification of red blood cell DNA and hybridization with allele-specific oligonucleotides (PCR-ASOs) is a genetic test that could identify mutations in the G6PD gene but is more complicated and not the first-line test for G6PD deficiency.

 

Educational objective:

 

G6PD deficiency due to sulphonamide antibiotic use, best diagnosed by a simple enzyme assay of red blood cell hemolysate. Other tests are more complex and less suited for this purpose.

 

Ref: Murray, pp 401-410. Scriver, pp 4517-4554. Lewis, pp 215-218.

questions.text: A 5-day-old female infant is examined with a cleft palate, congenital heart defect, postaxial polydactyly, a scalp defect, and distinctive facial features including hypertelorism. Karyotyping reveals a normal count of 46 chromosomes, but with additional genetic material on one of the chromosome 5 homologs. How is this chromosomal abnormality best categorized?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Unbalanced rearrangement

 

Option D:

 

  • Extra material / extra chromatin seen on chromosome 5 implies recombination of chromosome 5 DNA with that of another chromosome to produce a rearranged chromosome.
  • As this rearranged chromosome 5 takes the place of a normal chromosome 5, there is no change in number of the autosomes (non-sex chromosomes) or sex chromosomes (X and Y chromosomes)
  • The patient’s clinical findings are similar to trisomy 13 or Patau syndrome, suggesting that the extra material on chromosome 5 is derived from the long arm of chromosome 13.
  • With this interpretation, the aberration would be more specifically described as duplication 13q (dup[13q]) or as partial trisomy for 13q.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. & Option C: These chromosomal abnormalities involves changes in number (i.e., polyploidy and aneuploidy) or changes in structure (i.e., rearrangements such as translocations, rings, and inversions).

 

Option B: The scenario states that all cells examined from the patient (usually 11-25 cells) have the same chromosomal constitution, ruling out mosaicism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extra material on chromosome 5 indicates an unbalanced chromosomal rearrangement, where there is extra genetic material present without a corresponding loss elsewhere. This can lead to a genetic surplus or deficiency, causing developmental and physical abnormalities such as those observed in the infant.

 

Ref: Harper 31/ e: p 877-879.
